In an instant, he again gave rise to a compassionate mind. Because of his compassionate mind, milk flowed from all the pores of his body, surpassing the previous amount many times.

Seeing the ghosts satiated, he further observes his own body and sees fire coming out from the soles of his feet, burning the beings in front and the trees, all completely consumed.
At that time, if he sees many different kinds, he further focuses his attention and observes his own body, causing his mind to be unmoving, tranquil, and without thought.
Since there are no thoughts, he should make a vow, saying:

Having made this vow, he then sees the ground in front of him like lapis lazuli. Below the lapis lazuli, there is golden-colored water. He sees his own body the same as the ground and the same color as the water.
The water is warm, and in the water grows a tree like a tree of the seven treasures, with luxuriant branches and leaves.

Such wonderful fruits had a beautiful sound and were complete with fragrance and flavor.
I should eat now.
Having had this thought, he climbed up the tree and took the fruit to eat.
As soon as he got one fruit, its taste was sweet and delicious, incomparable to anything else.
After eating the fruit, he saw the tree wither, and the remaining three fruits still had light.
After eating the fruit, the body and mind are tranquil and free from thoughts of worry or joy.
Contemplate the mind and consciousness as a decaying dharma, arising from various sufferings.
The root of all sufferings is consciousness as a causal condition.
Now contemplate this consciousness, like bubbles on water, without any temporary stillness.
The four elements have no owner, the body has no self, and consciousness has no support.
In this way, contemplate these dharmas again and again, forty-nine times, contemplating that mind and consciousness are a decaying dharma.
At that time, one will see one's own body as white as a conch shell, with the joints supporting each other.
